text: MEN OF IRON
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: by Howard Pyle
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: INTRODUCTION
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The year 1400 opened with more than usual peacefulness in England. Only
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: a few months before, Richard II--weak, wicked, and treacherous--had been
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: dethroned, and Henry IV declared King in his stead. But it was only a
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: seeming peacefulness, lasting but for a little while; for though King
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Henry proved himself a just and a merciful man--as justice and mercy
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: went with the men of iron of those days--and though he did not care
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to shed blood needlessly, there were many noble families who had been
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: benefited by King Richard during his reign, and who had lost somewhat of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: their power and prestige from the coming in of the new King.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Among these were a number of great lords--the Dukes of Albemarle,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Surrey, and Exeter, the Marquis of Dorset, the Earl of Gloucester, and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: others--who had been degraded to their former titles and estates, from
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: which King Richard had lifted them. These and others brewed a secret
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: plot to take King Henry's life, which plot might have succeeded had not
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: one of their own number betrayed them.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Their plan had been to fall upon the King and his adherents, and to
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: massacre them during a great tournament, to be held at Oxford. But Henry
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: did not appear at the lists; whereupon, knowing that he had been lodging
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: at Windsor with only a few attendants, the conspirators marched thither
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: against him. In the mean time the King had been warned of the plot,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: so that, instead of finding him in the royal castle, they discovered
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: through their scouts that he had hurried to London, whence he was
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: even then marching against them at the head of a considerable army. So
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: nothing was left them but flight. Some betook themselves one way, some
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: another; some sought sanctuary here, some there; but one and another,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: they were all of them caught and killed.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The Earl of Kent--one time Duke of Surrey--and the Earl of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Salisbury were beheaded in the market-place at Cirencester; Lord Le
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Despencer--once the Earl of Gloucester--and Lord Lumley met the same
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: fate at Bristol; the Earl of Huntingdon was taken in the Essex fens,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: carried to the castle of the Duke of Gloucester, whom he had betrayed
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to his death in King Richard's time, and was there killed by the castle
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: people. Those few who found friends faithful and bold enough to afford
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: them shelter, dragged those friends down in their own ruin.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Just such a case was that of the father of the boy hero of this
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: story, the blind Lord Gilbert Reginald Falworth, Baron of Falworth and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Easterbridge, who, though having no part in the plot, suffered through
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: it ruin, utter and complete.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: He had been a faithful counsellor and adviser to King Richard, and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: perhaps it was this, as much and more than his roundabout connection
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: with the plot, that brought upon him the punishment he suffered.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: CHAPTER 1
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Myles Falworth was but eight years of age at that time, and it was only
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: afterwards, and when he grew old enough to know more of the ins and outs
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of the matter, that he could remember by bits and pieces the things that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: afterwards happened; how one evening a knight came clattering into the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: court-yard upon a horse, red-nostrilled and smeared with the sweat and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: foam of a desperate ride--Sir John Dale, a dear friend of the blind
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Lord.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Even though so young, Myles knew that something very serious had
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: happened to make Sir John so pale and haggard, and he dimly remembered
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: leaning against the knight's iron-covered knees, looking up into his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: gloomy face, and asking him if he was sick to look so strange. Thereupon
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: those who had been too troubled before to notice him, bethought
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: themselves of him, and sent him to bed, rebellious at having to go so
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: early.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: He remembered how the next morning, looking out of a window high up
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: under the eaves, he saw a great troop of horsemen come riding into the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: courtyard beneath, where a powdering of snow had whitened everything,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and of how the leader, a knight clad in black armor, dismounted and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: entered the great hall door-way below, followed by several of the band.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: He remembered how some of the castle women were standing in a frightened
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: group upon the landing of the stairs, talking together in low voices
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: about a matter he did not understand, excepting that the armed men who
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: had ridden into the courtyard had come for Sir John Dale. None of the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: women paid any attention to him; so, shunning their notice, he ran off
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: down the winding stairs, expecting every moment to be called back again
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: by some one of them.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: A crowd of castle people, all very serious and quiet, were gathered
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in the hall, where a number of strange men-at-arms lounged upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: benches, while two billmen in steel caps and leathern jacks stood
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: guarding the great door, the butts of their weapons resting upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: ground, and the staves crossed, barring the door-way.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: In the anteroom was the knight in black armor whom Myles had seen from
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the window. He was sitting at the table, his great helmet lying upon
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the bench beside him, and a quart beaker of spiced wine at his elbow. A
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: clerk sat at the other end of the same table, with inkhorn in one hand
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and pen in the other, and a parchment spread in front of him.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Master Robert, the castle steward, stood before the knight, who every
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: now and then put to him a question, which the other would answer, and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the clerk write the answer down upon the parchment.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: His father stood with his back to the fireplace, looking down upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: floor with his blind eyes, his brows drawn moodily together, and the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: scar of the great wound that he had received at the tournament at
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: York--the wound that had made him blind--showing red across his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: forehead, as it always did when he was angered or troubled.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: There was something about it all that frightened Myles, who crept to his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: father's side, and slid his little hand into the palm that hung limp and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: inert. In answer to the touch, his father grasped the hand tightly,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: but did not seem otherwise to notice that he was there. Neither did
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the black knight pay any attention to him, but continued putting his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: questions to Master Robert.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Then, suddenly, there was a commotion in the hall without, loud voices,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and a hurrying here and there. The black knight half arose, grasping a
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: heavy iron mace that lay upon the bench beside him, and the next moment
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Sir John Dale himself, as pale as death, walked into the antechamber. He
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: stopped in the very middle of the room. "I yield me to my Lord's grace
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and mercy," said he to the black knight, and they were the last words he
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: ever uttered in this world.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The black knight shouted out some words of command, and swinging up the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: iron mace in his hand, strode forward clanking towards Sir John, who
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: raised his arm as though to shield himself from the blow. Two or three
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of those who stood in the hall without came running into the room with
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: drawn swords and bills, and little Myles, crying out with terror, hid
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his face in his father's long gown.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The next instant came the sound of a heavy blow and of a groan, then
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: another blow and the sound of one falling upon the ground. Then the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: clashing of steel, and in the midst Lord Falworth crying, in a dreadful
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: voice, "Thou traitor! thou coward! thou murderer!"
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Master Robert snatched Myles away from his father, and bore him out of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the room in spite of his screams and struggles, and he remembered just
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: one instant's sight of Sir John lying still and silent upon his face,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and of the black knight standing above him, with the terrible mace in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his hand stained a dreadful red.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: It was the next day that Lord and Lady Falworth and little Myles,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: together with three of the more faithful of their people, left the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: castle.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: His memory of past things held a picture for Myles of old Diccon Bowman
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: standing over him in the silence of midnight with a lighted lamp in his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: hand, and with it a recollection of being bidden to hush when he would
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: have spoken, and of being dressed by Diccon and one of the women,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: bewildered with sleep, shuddering and chattering with cold.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: He remembered being wrapped in the sheepskin that lay at the foot of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his bed, and of being carried in Diccon Bowman's arms down the silent
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: darkness of the winding stair-way, with the great black giant shadows
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: swaying and flickering upon the stone wall as the dull flame of the lamp
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: swayed and flickered in the cold breathing of the night air.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Below were his father and mother and two or three others. A stranger
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: stood warming his hands at a newly-made fire, and little Myles, as he
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: peeped from out the warm sheepskin, saw that he was in riding-boots and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: was covered with mud. He did not know till long years afterwards that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the stranger was a messenger sent by a friend at the King's court,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: bidding his father fly for safety.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: They who stood there by the red blaze of the fire were all very still,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: talking in whispers and walking on tiptoes, and Myles's mother hugged
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: him in her arms, sheepskin and all, kissing him, with the tears
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: streaming down her cheeks, and whispering to him, as though he could
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: understand their trouble, that they were about to leave their home
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: forever.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Then Diccon Bowman carried him out into the strangeness of the winter
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: midnight.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Outside, beyond the frozen moat, where the osiers, stood stark and stiff
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in their winter nakedness, was a group of dark figures waiting for them
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: with horses. In the pallid moonlight Myles recognized the well-known
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: face of Father Edward, the Prior of St. Mary's.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: After that came a long ride through that silent night upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: saddle-bow in front of Diccon Bowman; then a deep, heavy sleep, that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: fell upon him in spite of the galloping of the horses.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: When next he woke the sun was shining, and his home and his whole life
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: were changed.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: CHAPTER 2
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: From the time the family escaped from Falworth Castle that midwinter
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: night to the time Myles was sixteen years old he knew nothing of the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: great world beyond Crosbey-Dale. A fair was held twice in a twelvemonth
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: at the market-town of Wisebey, and three times in the seven years old
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Diccon Bowman took the lad to see the sights at that place. Beyond these
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: three glimpses of the outer world he lived almost as secluded a life as
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: one of the neighboring monks of St. Mary's Priory.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Crosbey-Holt, their new home, was different enough from Falworth or
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Easterbridge Castle, the former baronial seats of Lord Falworth. It was
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: a long, low, straw-thatched farm-house, once, when the church lands were
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: divided into two holdings, one of the bailiff's houses. All around were
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the fruitful farms of the priory, tilled by well-to-do tenant holders,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and rich with fields of waving grain, and meadow-lands where sheep and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: cattle grazed in flocks and herds; for in those days the church lands
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: were under church rule, and were governed by church laws, and there,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: when war and famine and waste and sloth blighted the outside world,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: harvests flourished and were gathered, and sheep were sheared and cows
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: were milked in peace and quietness.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The Prior of St. Mary's owed much if not all of the church's prosperity
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to the blind Lord Falworth, and now he was paying it back with a haven
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of refuge from the ruin that his former patron had brought upon himself
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: by giving shelter to Sir John Dale.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: I fancy that most boys do not love the grinding of school life--the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: lessons to be conned, the close application during study hours. It is
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: not often pleasant to brisk, lively lads to be so cooped up. I wonder
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: what the boys of to-day would have thought of Myles's training. With him
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: that training was not only of the mind, but of the body as well, and for
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: seven years it was almost unremitting. "Thou hast thine own way to
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: make in the world, sirrah," his father said more than once when the boy
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: complained of the grinding hardness of his life, and to make one's way
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in those days meant a thousand times more than it does now; it meant not
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: only a heart to feel and a brain to think, but a hand quick and strong
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to strike in battle, and a body tough to endure the wounds and blows in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: return. And so it was that Myles's body as well as his mind had to be
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: trained to meet the needs of the dark age in which he lived.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Every morning, winter or summer, rain or shine he tramped away six long
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: miles to the priory school, and in the evenings his mother taught him
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: French.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Myles, being prejudiced in the school of thought of his day, rebelled
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: not a little at that last branch of his studies. "Why must I learn that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: vile tongue?" said he.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Call it not vile," said the blind old Lord, grimly; "belike, when thou
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: art grown a man, thou'lt have to seek thy fortune in France land, for
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: England is haply no place for such as be of Falworth blood." And in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: after-years, true to his father's prediction, the "vile tongue" served
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: him well.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: As for his physical training, that pretty well filled up the hours
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: between his morning studies at the monastery and his evening studies
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: at home. Then it was that old Diccon Bowman took him in hand, than whom
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: none could be better fitted to shape his young body to strength and his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: hands to skill in arms. The old bowman had served with Lord Falworth's
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: father under the Black Prince both in France and Spain, and in long
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: years of war had gained a practical knowledge of arms that few could
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: surpass. Besides the use of the broadsword, the short sword, the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: quarter-staff, and the cudgel, he taught Myles to shoot so skilfully
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: with the long-bow and the cross-bow that not a lad in the country-side
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: was his match at the village butts. Attack and defence with the lance,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and throwing the knife and dagger were also part of his training.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Then, in addition to this more regular part of his physical training,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Myles was taught in another branch not so often included in the military
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: education of the day--the art of wrestling. It happened that a fellow
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: lived in Crosbey village, by name Ralph-the-Smith, who was the greatest
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: wrestler in the country-side, and had worn the champion belt for three
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: years. Every Sunday afternoon, in fair weather, he came to teach Myles
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the art, and being wonderfully adept in bodily feats, he soon grew so
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: quick and active and firm-footed that he could cast any lad under twenty
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: years of age living within a range of five miles.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "It is main ungentle armscraft that he learneth," said Lord Falworth one
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: day to Prior Edward. "Saving only the broadsword, the dagger, and the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: lance, there is but little that a gentleman of his strain may use.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Neth'less, he gaineth quickness and suppleness, and if he hath true
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: blood in his veins he will acquire knightly arts shrewdly quick when the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: time cometh to learn them."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: But hard and grinding as Myles's life was, it was not entirely without
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: pleasures. There were many boys living in Crosbey-Dale and the village;
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: yeomen's and farmers' sons, to be sure, but, nevertheless, lads of his
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: own age, and that, after all, is the main requirement for friendship in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: boyhood's world. Then there was the river to bathe in; there were the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: hills and valleys to roam over, and the wold and woodland, with their
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: wealth of nuts and birds'-nests and what not of boyhood's treasures.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Once he gained a triumph that for many a day was very sweet under the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: tongue of his memory. As was said before, he had been three times to the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: market-town at fair-time, and upon the last of these occasions he had
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: fought a bout of quarterstaff with a young fellow of twenty, and had
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: been the conqueror. He was then only a little over fourteen years old.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Old Diccon, who had gone with him to the fair, had met some cronies of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his own, with whom he had sat gossiping in the ale-booth, leaving Myles
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: for the nonce to shift for himself. By-and-by the old man had noticed
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: a crowd gathered at one part of the fair-ground, and, snuffing a fight,

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

text: CHAPTER 17
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The summer passed away, and the bleak fall came. Myles had long since
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: accepted his position as one set apart from the others of his kind, and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in the household in waiting upon the Earl. I cannot say that it never
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: have presently to speak.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: And then he had so much the more time to himself. The other lads were
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in which they would liked to have taken part. Myles was always free
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: he was not long in gaining a sort of second-hand knowledge of all the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: family. My Lady, a thin, sallow, faded dame, not yet past middle age,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: but looking ten years older. The Lady Anne, the daughter of the house;
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and haughty, Myles heard the squires say. Lady Alice, the Earl of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: rendered him reconciled him not a little to the Earl's obvious neglect.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: days lived in state little less royal than royalty itself.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: meeting them in Lord George's apartments in the south wing of the great
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: out for friendly notice, giving him a nod or a word in passing.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Every season has its pleasures for boys, and the constant change that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: they bring is one of the greatest delights of boyhood's days.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: filled Myles's heart in after-years with an indefinable pleasure, was
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron

text: In Myles Falworth's day one of the greatest ceremonies of courtly life
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: was that of the bestowal of knighthood by the King, with the honors of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the Bath. By far the greater number of knights were at that time created
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: by other knights, or by nobles, or by officers of the crown. To be
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: knighted by the King in person distinguished the recipient for life. It
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: was this signal honor that the Earl, for his own purposes, wished Myles
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to enjoy, and for this end he had laid not a few plans.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The accolade was the term used for the creation of a knight upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: field of battle. It was a reward of valor or of meritorious service, and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: was generally bestowed in a more or less off-hand way; but the ceremony
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of the Bath was an occasion of the greatest courtly moment, and it was
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: thus that Myles Falworth was to be knighted in addition to the honor of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: a royal belting.

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: deny my treason, which denial I could not before make, being blind and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: helpless, and mine enemies strong and malignant. But now, sire, Heaven
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: hath sent me help, and therefore I do acclaim before thee that my
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: accuser, William Bushy Brookhurst, Earl of Alban, is a foul and an
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: attainted liar in all that he hath accused me of. To uphold which
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: allegation, and to defend me, who am blinded by his unknightliness, I do
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: offer a champion to prove all that I say with his body in combat."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The Earl of Mackworth darted a quick look at Myles, who came forward the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: moment his father had ended, and kneeled beside him. The King offered no
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: interruption to his speech, but he bent a look heavy with anger upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: young man.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "My gracious Lord and King," said Myles, "I, the son of the accused, do
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: offer myself as his champion in this cause, beseeching thee of thy grace
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: leave to prove the truth of the same, being a belted knight by thy grace
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and of thy creation and the peer of any who weareth spurs." Thereupon,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: rising, he drew his iron gauntlet from his girdle, and flung it clashing
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: down upon the floor, and with his heart swelling within him with anger
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and indignation and pity of his blind father, he cried, in a loud
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: voice, "I do accuse thee, William of Alban, that thou liest vilely as
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: aforesaid, and here cast down my gage, daring thee to take it up."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The Earl of Alban made as though he would accept the challenge, but the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: King stopped him hastily.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Stop!" he cried, harshly. "Touch not the gage! Let it lie--let it lie,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: I tell thee, my Lord! Now then," said he, turning to the others, "tell
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: me what meaneth all this coil? Who brought this man hither?"
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: He looked from one to another of those who stood silently around, but no
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: one answered.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "I see," said he, "ye all have had to do with it. It is as my Lord of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Alban sayeth; ye are his enemies, and ye are my enemies as well. In this
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: I do smell a vile plot. I cannot undo what I have done, and since I have
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: made this young man a knight with mine own hands, I cannot deny that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: he is fit to challenge my Lord of Alban. Ne'theless, the High Court of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Chivalry shall adjudge this case. Meantime," said he, turning to the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Earl Marshal, who was present, "I give thee this attainted Lord in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: charge. Convey him presently to the Tower, and let him abide our
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: pleasure there. Also, thou mayst take up yon gage, and keep it till it
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: is redeemed according to our pleasure."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: He stood thoughtfully for a moment, and then raising his eyes, looked
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: fixedly at the Earl of Mackworth. "I know," he said, "that I be a right
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: sick man, and there be some who are already plotting to overthrow those
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: who have held up my hand with their own strength for all these years."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Then speaking more directly: "My Lord Earl of Mackworth, I see your hand
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in this before all others. It was thou who so played upon me as to get
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: me to knight this young man, and thus make him worthy to challenge my
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Lord of Alban. It was thy doings that brought him here to-day, backed
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: by mine own sons and my brother and by these noblemen." Then turning
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: suddenly to the Earl of Alban: "Come, my Lord," said he; "I am aweary
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: with all this coil. Lend me thine arm to leave this place." So it
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: was that he left the room, leaning upon the Earl of Alban's arm, and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Your Royal Highness," said the Earl Marshal, "I must e'en do the King's
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Do thy duty," said the Prince. "We knew it must come to this. Meanwhile
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: he is to be a prisoner of honor, and see that he be well lodged and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

text: CHAPTER 31
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: It was not until the end of July that the High Court of Chivalry
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: rendered its judgment. There were many unusual points in the case, some
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of which bore heavily against Lord Falworth, some of which were in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his favor. He was very ably defended by the lawyers whom the Earl
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of Mackworth had engaged upon his side; nevertheless, under ordinary
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: circumstances, the judgment, no doubt, would have been quickly rendered
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: against him. As it was, however, the circumstances were not ordinary,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and it was rendered in his favor. The Court besought the King to grant
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the ordeal by battle, to accept Lord Falworth's champion, and to appoint
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the time and place for the meeting.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The decision must have been a most bitter, galling one for the sick
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: King. He was naturally of a generous, forgiving nature, but Lord
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Falworth in his time of power had been an unrelenting and fearless
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: opponent, and his Majesty who, like most generous men, could on
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: occasions be very cruel and intolerant, had never forgiven him. He had
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: steadily thrown the might of his influence with the Court against the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Falworths' case, but that influence was no longer all-powerful for good
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: or ill. He was failing in health, and it could only be a matter of a few
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: years, probably of only a few months, before his successor sat upon the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: throne.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Upon the other hand, the Prince of Wales's faction had been steadily,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and of late rapidly, increasing in power, and in the Earl of Mackworth,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: its virtual head, it possessed one of the most capable politicians and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: astute intriguers in Europe. So, as the outcome of all the plotting and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: counter-plotting, scheming and counter-scheming, the case was decided in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Lord Falworth's favor. The knowledge of the ultimate result was known
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to the Prince of Wales's circle almost a week before it was finally
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: decided. Indeed, the Earl of Mackworth had made pretty sure of that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: result before he had summoned Myles from France, but upon the King it
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: fell like the shock of a sudden blow. All that day he kept himself in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: moody seclusion, nursing his silent, bitter anger, and making only
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: one outbreak, in which he swore by the Holy Rood that should Myles be
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: worsted in the encounter, he would not take the battle into his own
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: hands, but would suffer him to be slain, and furthermore, that should
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the Earl show signs of failing at any time, he would do all in his power
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to save him. One of the courtiers who had been present, and who was
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: secretly inclined to the Prince of Wales's faction, had repeated this
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: speech at Scotland Yard, and the Prince had said, "That meaneth, Myles,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: that thou must either win or die."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "And so I would have it to be, my Lord," Myles had answered.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: It was not until nearly a fortnight after the decision of the Court of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Chivalry had been rendered that the King announced the time and place
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: of battle--the time to be the 3d of September, the place to be
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Smithfield--a spot much used for such encounters.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: During the three weeks or so that intervened between this announcement
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and the time of combat, Myles went nearly every day to visit the lists
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in course of erection. Often the Prince went with him; always two or
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: three of his friends of the Scotland Yard court accompanied him.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: The lists were laid out in the usual form. The true or principal list in
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: which the combatants were to engage was sixty yards long and forty yards
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: wide; this rectangular space being surrounded by a fence about six feet
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: high, painted vermilion. Between the fence and the stand where the King
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: and the spectators sat, and surrounding the central space, was the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: outer or false list, also surrounded by a fence. In the false list the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Constable and the Marshal and their followers and attendants were to be
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: stationed at the time of battle to preserve the general peace during the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: contest between the principals.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: One day as Myles, his princely patron, and his friends entered the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: barriers, leaving their horses at the outer gate, they met the Earl of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Alban and his followers, who were just quitting the lists, which they
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: also were in the habit of visiting nearly every day. As the two parties
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: passed one another, the Earl spoke to a gentleman walking beside him and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: in a voice loud enough to be clearly overheard by the others: "Yonder
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: is the young sprig of Falworth," said he. "His father, my Lords, is
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: not content with forfeiting his own life for his treason, but must,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: forsooth, throw away his son's also. I have faced and overthrown many a
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: better knight than that boy."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Myles heard the speech, and knew that it was intended for him to hear
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: it; but he paid no attention to it, walking composedly at the Prince's
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: side. The Prince had also overheard it, and after a little space of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: silence asked, "Dost thou not feel anxiety for thy coming battle,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Myles?"
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Yea, my Lord," said Myles; "sometimes I do feel anxiety, but not such
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: as my Lord of Alban would have me feel in uttering the speech that he
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: spake anon. It is anxiety for my father's sake and my mother's sake that
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: I feel, for truly there are great matters for them pending upon this
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: fight. Ne'theless, I do know that God will not desert me in my cause,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: for verily my father is no traitor."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "But the Earl of Alban," said the Prince, gravely, "is reputed one of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the best-skilled knights in all England; moreover, he is merciless and
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: without generosity, so that an he gain aught advantage over thee, he
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: will surely slay thee."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "I am not afraid, my Lord," said Myles, still calmly and composedly.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Nor am I afraid for thee, Myles," said the Prince, heartily, putting
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his arm, as he spoke, around the young man's shoulder; "for truly, wert
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: thou a knight of forty years, instead of one of twenty, thou couldst not
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: bear thyself with more courage."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: As the time for the duel approached, the days seemed to drag themselves
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: along upon leaden feet; nevertheless, the days came and went, as all
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: days do, bringing with them, at last, the fateful 3d of September.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Early in the morning, while the sun was still level and red, the Prince
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: himself, unattended, came to Myles's apartment, in the outer room of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: which Gascoyne was bustling busily about arranging the armor piece by
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: piece; renewing straps and thongs, but not whistling over his work as he
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: usually did. The Prince nodded to him, and then passed silently through
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: to the inner chamber. Myles was upon his knees, and Father Ambrose,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the Prince's chaplain, was beside him. The Prince stood silently at the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: door, until Myles, having told his last bead, rose and turned towards
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: him.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "My dear Lord," said the young knight, "I give you gramercy for the
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: great honor you do me in coming so early for to visit me."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: "Nay, Myles, give me no thanks," said the Prince, frankly reaching him
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: his hand, which Myles took and set to his lips. "I lay bethinking me of
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: thee this morning, while yet in bed, and so, as I could not sleep any
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: more, I was moved to come hither to see thee."
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Quite a number of the Prince's faction were at the breakfast at Scotland
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: Yard that morning; among others, the Earl of Mackworth. All were more or
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: the coming battle. If Alban conquered, he would be more powerful to harm
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: them and to revenge himself upon them than ever, and Myles was a very
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: young champion upon whom to depend. Myles himself, perhaps, showed as
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: little anxiety as any; he certainly ate more heartily of his breakfast
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: that morning than many of the others.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: stairs," said he; "if thou wouldst go to the Tower to visit thy father,
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: thee?"
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: so pleased to give them leave to go," answered Myles.
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: knight."

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

text: her lips trembled, and she turned her face quickly away, pressing
title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron

title: Men of Iron
author: Pyle, Howard

title: Men of Iron
